Tunable products of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural oxidation by Zn/Co-ZIF derived catalysts Yingjie Li Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Data curation a Yuanyuan Wang Investigation a Hui Gao Investigation a Zhijie Zhang Investigation a Lungang Chen Methodology Funding acquisition b ⁎ Xiaoyuan Liao Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Methodology a ⁎ a College of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Tianjin University of Science and Technology, Tianjin, China College of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Tianjin University of Science and Technology Tianjin China College of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Tianjin University of Science and Technology, Tianjin, China b Key Laboratory of Energy Thermal Conversion and Control of Ministry of Education, School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China Key Laboratory of Energy Thermal Conversion and Control of Ministry of Education, School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University Nanjing 210096 China Key Laboratory of Energy Thermal Conversion and Control of Ministry of Education, School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. As a bio-based platform compound, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) can be effectively converted into other high value-added derivatives. Here we report two non-noble metal catalysts for the selective oxidation of HMF, NC and Co@NC are easily obtained by pyrolysis of ZIF-8 and ZIF-67, respectively. The NC and Co@NC catalysts oxidized HMF to FFCA (Select. 95 %) and FDCA (Select. 98 %), respectively, using O2 as oxidant. Experimental and theoretical studies show that pyridinic N and graphitic N in NC has high catalytic activity for the oxidation of carbonyl groups in HMF to FFCA, while the synergistic effect of Co-N in Co@NC can completely oxidize HMF to FDCA. DFT calculations show that, compared with NC, the Co@NC containing Co-N exhibits a lower energy barrier during the aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA. And Co-N leads to the conversion of electrons from N to Co and promotes the activation of O2 to form O2 -, and then oxidize HMF to FDCA. Interestingly, our reaction system is universal, and could achieve almost 100 % conversion of various furfural substrates to corresponding carboxylic acid. This study may provide a new/highly efficient catalysts for biomass conversion. Graphical Abstract Keywords HMF FDCA Co@NC Selective oxidation Biomass Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is recommended as some key platform molecules in the biorefinery process that can be used to generate a series of value-added derivatives [1], such as 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA) and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) etc. ( Scheme 1). Among them, FFCA has good application prospects in fuels, chemical intermediates and drugs, especially in the preparation of surfactants and resins [2]. Especially, FDCA, prepared by oxidation, is listed by the US Department of Energy as one of the top 12 value-added chemicals in biomass as an effective replacement for terephthalic acid as a polymer monomer for the synthesis of polyethylene furanoate (PEF). The oxidation of HMF has been extensively investigated to date, and various materials have been used. Strong oxidants such as KMnO4 and Cr2O7 2- [3] were used for the oxidation of HMF, obviously this method releases a large amount of waste and is not sustainable. Nowadays, metal oxide and noble metal are two common catalysts studied for alcohol oxidation. The more abundant transition metal oxides such as Co3O4 and ZnO usually have fewer uncoordinated electrons or empty orbitals, making it difficult to coordinate or adsorb organic substrates [4,5], resulting in low catalytic activity, and often requiring the synergy of other noble metals to achieve good catalytic performance. Xu et al. proposed using NMP as solvent and FeMo6 as catalyst to oxidize HMF to FFCA under normal pressure [6]. Zheng et al. reported Pt/CeO2@C as a catalyst for the aerobic oxidation of HMF [7]. Bordeiasu et al. studied the catalytic oxidation of HMF on cobalt-based MOFs, and generated 89 % HMFCA selectivity in the presence of t-BuOOH oxidant and acetonitrile solvent [8]. Saxena et al. developed ultra-low amounts of precious metal nanoparticles loaded on hollow zeolite capsules (MCM-22 and ZSM-5), demonstrating that metal nanoparticles@zeolite can make the conversion of HMF > 90 % [9]. However, the high price of precious metals and the shortage of resources prevent them from being widely used. In recent years, nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) catalysts have been extensively investigated for their excellent performance, possibly due to the different atomic radii and bond lengths of the carbon and nitrogen atoms, resulting in the formation of surface defect sites in the carbon skeleton, which in turn facilitate the reaction through charge transfer [10]. Li et al. established a method for nitric acid to promote the catalytic oxidation of HMF in the presence of nitrogen-doped carbon materials [11]. In particular, the introduction of atomically dispersed metal atoms into the carrier as promoters is a new strategy to improve the catalytic performance of multiphase catalysts, and the nitrozeolite imidazole salt skeleton is an ideal precursor for the preparation of nitrogen-doped carbon-based catalysts [12,13]. Compared with traditional nanomaterials, ZIFs materials do not agglomerate during pyrolysis due to their tunable structure and ordered organic ligands, and the active centers are highly dispersed. This MOF template metal-carbon composite catalyst has been proved to have good application prospects in hydrogenation and aerobic oxidation. Zhao et al. used ZIF-67 as a template to prepare Co-Nx catalyst with excellent hydrogenation performance [14]. In this work, we have prepared low-cost and sustainable NC materials and Co@NC materials by pyrolysis of ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 under Ar, respectively. Among them, Co@NC contains metal Co and CoN4 components. Dispersion of cobalt nanoparticles on n-doped carbon carriers enhanced the catalytic activity and improved the stability of the catalyst. In the oxidation of HMF, NC and Co@NC were obtained by changing the precursor of ZIFs, so as to achieve highly selective generation of different target products FFCA and FDCA. This work would provide support in development of non-noble metal-based efficient and environmental-friendly catalyst for the application in HMF production. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts synthesis As shown in Scheme 2, ZIFs are prepared according to our published procedure [15]: 2.910 g Co (NO3)2•6 H2O was dissolved in 25 mL of methanol as solution A and 6.568 g of 2-methylimidazole was dissolved in 25 mL of methanol as solution B. Then solution A was introduced into solution B and stirred thoroughly to encourage the reaction to occur. After the reaction was complete, the ZIF-67 is obtained after washed with methanol three times and drying and grinding. The synthesis method of ZIF-8 is similar, only the cobalt source is replaced by the zinc source. Then, ZIF-67 and ZIF-8 were pyrolyzed 5 h at 800°C in Ar atmosphere to synthesize Co@NC and NC, respectively. 2.2 Characterization Bruker AXS D8-Focus diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (Germany) diffractometer was used to record X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) pattern. The XPS analyses were carried out with a Kratos AXIS Supra spectrometer using a monochromatic Al K(alpha) source (15 mA, 15 kV). A field emission microscope (Hitachi FESEM-4800) was used scanning electron microscope (SEM) images. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas were obtained by ASAP 2020 plus HD88 at a liquid nitrogen temperature of 77 K, and the pore size was derived from the adsorption branch of the N2 isotherm. Electron spin resonance (ESR) analysis of the catalysts was carried out on a Bruker A300 spectrometer. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD-CO2/NH3) were performed on the Quantachrome TPR Win v3.52, 50 mg samples were pretreated in He (120 mL/min) for 60 min at 300 °C to remove moisture from the catalyst pores, after cooling to 50 °C, purged in CO2 (NH3) stream for 30 min, treated in He for 60 min to remove physically adsorbed gas, then the sample was raised to 800 °C (10 °C/min), the signal by monitored by the TCD. 2.3 Catalytic performance and chemical analysis In a typical reaction, the aerobic oxidation of the HMF takes place in a batch-type Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The HMF methanol solution (20 mL), catalyst were mixed and sealed in a reaction vessel with O2 as oxidant 0.6 MPa and stirred at reaction temperature until the reaction was complete. Then the reaction kettle was cooled and centrifuged, and the products were analyzed by Agilent 1260 Infinity HPLC apparatus. The experimental results were analyzed according to the following formula: (1) Conv. (%) = n reactant , initial − n reactant , final n reactant , initial × 100 % (2) Select. (%) = n product n reactant , initial − n reactant , final × 100 % 2.4 Computational methods All Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were based on the generalized gradient method (GGA) and using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) function in the Materials Studio software. The energy cutoff was set to 400 eV. At least 15 Å vacuum layer was applied in z-direction of the slab models, preventing the vertical interactions between slabs. The transition state (TS) between the reactants and their products is determined by the nudge elastic band (NEB) method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 Structure and morphology The XRD profiles of synthesized ZIFs materials including ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 were consistent with previously reported results ( Fig. 1A) [15]. As seen in Fig. 1B, ZIF-8 pyrolysis-derived NC has a broad peak near 2θ = 24° and 44°, corresponding to the (002) plane of graphite carbon and (101) plane [11,16], respectively. The diffraction peak intensity of the (101) surface is low, indicating that sample has condensed in the layer and N atoms are doped in the graphite layer, which proves that NC was prepared successfully and no residual Zn in NC. The XRD pattern of Co@NC is shown in Fig. 1B. The presence of graphite carbon was found at 24°, and the diffraction peaks of metal Co were found at 44.3°, 51.5°, and 76.1°. The SEM images show that the average diameters of the catalysts are about 1 μm (Co@NC) and 240 nm (NC), respectively. In particular, compared to ZIFs ( Fig. 2A,B), there is still some shrinkage morphology of ZIF-67 in the Co@NC obtained after pyrolysis and carbonization (Fig. 2B1), and a polyhedral morphology with concave interior cavities and the rough surface. This is because during pyrolysis, the precursors of ZIFs contract in each direction, which also promotes the increase of surface area, thereby exposing more metal check points and accelerating mass charge transport [17]. The related energy dispersion X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) (Fig. 2B2-B5) shows that Co, N, C are uniformly dispersed, while the morphology of NC is irregular spherical due to the loss of Zn (Fig. 2A1). N2 adsorption/desorption test (Fig. S1) showed that both samples had obvious mesopores. Co@NC had a higher BET surface area (230.4 m2·g−1), while the BET surface area of NC was only 137.1 m2·g−1. The pore size distribution curves confirm that the average pore sizes of Co@NC and NC are 3.7 nm and 4.5 nm, respectively. Obviously, after the ZIFs material was pyrolyzed at high temperature, the two samples still maintained a high specific surface area with mesoporous, and for Co@NC, the high specific area also made most of the Co species well dispersed, which was conducive to exposure and mass transfer. 3.1.2 XPS As shown in Fig. 3A, the XPS survey scan spectrum of all samples showed that C1s peak, N1s peak and O1s peak were observed at 285 eV, 402 eV and 535 eV, respectively, where the O1s peak may be due to adsorbed oxygen or water in the air. And Co@NC sample has a Co2p peak centered on 780 eV. N atoms are particularly important in reactions involving NC catalysts, so N1s high-resolution spectra of NC is exhibited in Fig. 3B, which can be deconvolved into four sub-peaks around 398.4 eV, 400 eV, 401.2 eV and 402 eV, corresponding to pyridinic nitrogen (N1), pyrrolic nitrogen (N2), graphitic nitrogen (N3) and pyridine oxide nitrogen (N4), respectively [18]. And in the C1s deconvolution spectra, subpeaks of sp3 C−C (284.7 eV, C1), C-N (285.8 eV, C2) and graphitic carbon (288.8 eV, C3) were observed (Fig. 3C). The above results show the successful synthesis of nitrogen-doped carbon materials, agreeing with the XRD results [19,20]. In addition, we analyzed the XPS of the spent catalyst NC for analysis (Fig. S2A and Table S1) and found that N1, N2, N3 and N4 peaks are still retained, but pyridinic nitrogen and graphitic nitrogen decreased while pyrrolic nitrogen increased and pyridine oxide nitrogen, indicating that pyridinic nitrogen and graphitic nitrogen are key components in this reaction process [21,22]. Similarly, in order to further analyze the specific composition of Co element in Co@NC sample, the spectra were deconvolved into 3 peaks (Fig. 3D). The subpeak at 778.6 eV is attributable to metallic cobalt (Co0), 780.4 eV to Co-Nx, which is formed by doping the Co2 + species with N, and the peak at 786 eV is generally considered a satellite peak, attributed to Electron-deficient Co species (Co-O/Co-N) [23]. The high-resolution spectra of C1s can be deconvolved into 3 carbon species attributed to C-C (C1), C-N (C2), graphitic carbon (C3) and N1 s were deconvolved in pyridinic nitrogen (N1), pyrrolic nitrogen (N2), graphitic nitrogen (N3), pyridine oxide nitrogen (N4) (Fig. S3). Compared with NC, the N1 peak has a significant positive shift of 0.20 eV, confirming the presence of Co@NC metal pyridine N group, whose π electrons interact strongly with cobalt, preferentially nucleating cobalt at the sp2-N position, reducing the aggregation of cobalt nanoparticles [24], which is consistent with the previous characterization results. Obviously, the presence of Co and N species may be the key factors affecting the reactivity, and we further analyzed the XPS results of Co@NC catalysts before and after the reaction. Interestingly, the content of Co-Nx species decreased sharply from 74.29 % of fresh Co@NC to 26.97 % of Co@NC-re (Fig. S1B and Table S2), so Co-Nx was considered to be the activity check point of HMF catalytic conversion [25]. In addition, there are still four types of nitrogen species before and after the reaction of the Co@NC catalyst, among which pyridinic N (N1) is significantly reduced from 15.49 % to 6.50 % after the reaction (Fig. S3, S4 and Table S3), indicating that pyridine nitrogen plays a certain role in the reaction, which is consistent with the NC catalyst in the previous article, but the generation of FDCA is difficult to achieve only by relying on N species, and it needs to be fully realized by means of the Co-N coordination structure. Electronic interactions between N and embedded Co nanoparticles lead to the conversion of electrons from N to Co [26], forming electron-rich active metal species promotes to the activation of the reactants. Furthermore, CO2-TPD (Fig. S5A) reveals the presence of substantial basic sites on both catalysts, attributed to the Lewis basic sites provided by pyridine N and Co-Nx. Specifically, the desorption peaks observed for the Co@NC between 600 °C and 700 °C are indicative of CO2 interaction with highly basic sites [27]. NH3-TPD (Fig. S5B) reveals that the introduction of Co doping substantially elevates the acid sites of Co@NC. The acid and base sites facilitates the adsorption of alcohol O-H bonds and the activation of aldehydes, consequently enhancing the catalytic oxidation of HMF [28,29]. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Catalyst, solvent, base and reaction times The catalytic activity of different samples was evaluated after oxidizing HMF in methanol for 4 h with O2 as oxidant and K2CO3 as alkoxide. As shown in Fig. 4A, when NC is used as the catalyst, the selectivity of its main product FFCA (Select. % = 86) and FDCA is only about 4 %. However, Co@NC catalyst in the oxidation performance evaluation of HMF, the main product is FDCA (Select. % = 58), and the selectivity of FFCA is 30 %. These data show that NC catalysts can catalyze the oxidation of HMF to FFCA, but its catalytic activity is still insufficient for further oxidation to FDCA, and Co@NC catalysts have a significant effect on the conversion of HMF to FDCA, which may be because the Co-doped NC material enhances the oxidation activity of the catalyst. We optimized the reactions involving Co@NC in greater detail. Firstly, we examined the effects of several solvents. The order of HMF conversion in different solvents is Methanol (40 %) > H2O (38 %) > DMF (35 %) > DMSO (10 %). Specifically, seen in Fig. 4B, in the methanol, the main products of HMF catalytic oxidation are FFCA (Select.% =79) and FDCA (Select.% =16), which are significantly stronger than those in water (FDCA Select.% =7). The main product is DFF and no FDCA in DMSO and DMF. Obviously, methanol is the best choice and reduces the occurrence of side reactions. The reasons for these differences may be due to the different solubility of FDCA and oxygen in different solvents, and its solubility in methanol is higher than that of other solvents, which is highly consistent with previous studies [30]. In this work, when water is used as the solvent, the conversion rate of HMF is close to that of methanol, but the selectivity of its target product is significantly lower than that of methanol, when water is used as the solvent, the purity and selectivity of the FDCA will be affected, which may be due to the formation of its by-product glycolic acid [31]. In addition, the polarity of the solvent also affects the oxidation process of HMF [28,32]. As seen in Fig. 4C, no matter what kind of base is added in the methanol medium, the conversion rate of HMF and the selectivity of FDCA will be significantly improved compared with pure methanol. This may be because the alkali can promote alkoxide formation and C-H bond activation in alcohol oxidation [33], further promoting the generation of FDCA. In addition, the use of alkali can neutralize FDCA and avoid FDCA adsorption on the catalyst surface, affecting the stability of catalyst activity. It is also important to prevent metal leaching formed by carboxylic acids rather than free acids [34,35]. When the weak base NaHCO3 is added, the conversion rate of HMF increases from 40 % to 84 %, and the selectivity of FDCA increases from 16 % to 41 %. When the medium and strong bases K2CO3 and NaOH are added, the conversion rate of HMF can reach 99 %, and the selectivity of FDCA is 58 % and 62 %, respectively. Moreover, Fig. 4D shows the effect of reaction time on the catalytic oxidation of HMF (25 mL methanol, 2K2CO3), during the whole oxidation process, the intermediate of catalytic conversion was always HMFCA, and no DFF was found, which indicated that the aldehyde group was more prone to oxidation than the hydroxyl group and revealed that the reaction path is HMF-HMFCA-FFCA-FDCA. In the initial stage of the reaction, HMF is rapidly converted into HMFCA and FFCA, and the conversion rate of HMF can reach 99 % in about 2 h. Between 3 and 20 h, FFCA and HMFCA continued to decrease to around 2 %, and the selectivity of FDCA increases rapidly from 45 % to 98 %, which may be because the generated FFCA is further converted into FDCA. Through the screening and optimization of the reaction parameters, it is found that under the conditions of catalyst dosage of 5 mg, methanol as solvent, temperature of 130 ℃, 0.6 MPa O2, and reaction time of 20 h, the Co@NC catalyst has high selective catalytic oxidation of HMF to prepare FDCA efficiency. At the same time, we compared the reaction process of NC catalyst under the same conditions, the reaction path is the same as that of Co@NC catalyst, but the reaction product is FFCA, and the selectivity in 20 h is 95 % (Fig. S6). FFCA can be detected in the reaction process involving both catalysts, which indicates that HMFCA is rapidly converted to FFCA, and trace amounts of FDCA can be detected in the reaction involving the NC catalyst, which indicates that the conversion of FFCA to FDCA is slow and painstaking, whereas basically all of FFCA is converted to FDCA in the reaction process involving the Co@NC catalyst. 3.2.2 Temperature and O2 pressure The reaction temperature is a necessary condition to affect the activity of the catalyst, so choosing the appropriate reaction degree can significantly increase the reaction rate and improve the selectivity of the target product. As shown in Fig. 5A,B, with the increase of temperature, the conversion rate of HMF and the selectivity of products are significantly improved. Obviously, the increase in temperature is conducive to the oxidation of HMF, but the high temperature will cause deep oxidation and polycondensation of HMF. In this reaction evaluation, the selectivity of the target product decreases after the reaction temperature rises to 150 °C. Therefore, the most suitable temperature we choose is 130 °C. On the other hand, O2 pressure also has a certain impact on the oxidation process. As shown in the Fig. 5C,D, the selective oxidation of HMF cannot occur in the atmosphere of an oxygen-free source gas. The increase of O2 pressure will increase the dissolved oxygen content in the reaction solution, thereby promoting the conversion of intermediate products to the final product FDCA, but the increase of O2 pressure blindly decreases the target product. This is because in the reaction process, in addition to the reaction of the target product, other oxidation side reactions will also occur, such as the open epoxidation of furan rings to generate CO or CO2. The increase of dissolved oxygen will also lead to the acceleration of the side reaction and compete with the main reaction. Overall, the oxidation performance of these two catalysts for the conversion of HMF to FFCA and FDCA was better than that of previous studies ( Table 1). NC can achieve the oxidation effect of noble metal catalysts such as Pd@NC and Pt/HAP in previous studies, Co@NC can match the effect of polymetallic synergistic catalysts (2 % AuPd (1:1)/IRA-743, Ce0.5Fe0.15Zr0.35O2). In addition, reusability tests (Fig. S7) showed that NC and Co@NC maintained excellent catalytic performance after four consecutive runs, indicating that our catalysts were stable. 3.2.3 DFT calculation A series of DFT calculations were performed to understand the nature of the catalytic activity of the two catalysts. As seen in Fig. S8, pyridinic nitrogen has the highest adsorption energy for HMF (Eads= −0.60 eV), followed by graphite nitrogen (Eads= −0.54 eV) and pyrrole nitrogen (Eads= −0.24 eV) in NC adsorption configuration, and the adsorption energy of Co@NC to HMF is much higher than that of NC (ΔEads= 4.9 eV > 0.6 eV), indicating that the material containing Co-N is more conducive to the adsorption of HMF, which further confirms that the active sites of the two catalysts for catalytic oxidation of HMF. The differential charge density distributions analysis ( Fig. 6A) were also used to study the electronic properties and synergistic interactions, and both NC, Co@NC exhibit symmetric charge distribution. The charge accumulation in the Co@NC model structure is mainly concentrated around the Co atom, which is formed by the electron transfer between Co and coordination N, so that the Co active sites generates more electron-rich catalytic active sites, which is conducive to the adsorption and activation of O2 and generate superoxide radicals [43]. And Bader charge analysis (Fig. 6B) shows that the electron transfer from Co@NC to O2 is stronger (0.48 e-) compared to NC (0.30 e-), indicating that the embedded cobalt nanoparticles and doped nitrogen synergistically promote the activation of preabsorbed O2, and electrons are transferred from the Co 3d orbital to the 2P antibound orbital of adsorb O2, and generate superoxide radicals convert HMF to FDCA [19,44]. Fig. 6C shows the projected densities of states (PDOS) for catalysts, it is clear that the center of the p-band of Co@NC (-4.7896) has shifted up by 0.59 eV compared to NC (-5.3794), higher p-band center and the adsorbed oxygen intermediate occupy fewer antibound states [45], so Co@NC is more conducive to electron transfer, prefer to activate the reactants. We further carried out inhibition experiments to determine reactive oxygen species of HMF oxidation. Fig. 7A shows that, 1,4-benzoquinone scavenger could significantly suppress HMF oxidation for both reactions. EPR (Fig. 7B) further confirmed that O2 - is the main reactive oxygen species [46]. It can be found that the O2 - produced by Co@NC are significantly more than NC, which maybe the main reason of Co@NC could archived completely oxidization. 3.2.4 Reaction mechanism In summary, NC and Co@NC catalysts catalyzed the oxidation of HMF to produce different target products due to the embedding of Co nanoparticles in N-doped carbon. The surface adsorption properties and catalytic active sites of NC and Co@NC catalysts were systematically characterized and analyzed based above results, the reaction mechanisms of the two catalytic oxidation processes are depicted in Fig. 8A. Pyridinic nitrogen and graphitic N in NC can be used as a catalytic active sites for the selective oxidation of HMF to FFCA [10]. Among them, the Lewis base sites provided by pyridinic N can effectively oxidize the -OH of HMF to generate HMFCA, while when graphite N forms three σ-bonds and one π-bond with neighboring carbon atoms, an unpaired electron is formed on the p-orbital, which attracts O2 on the surface of NC. After accepting unpaired electrons, reactive oxygen species will be formed, and the hydroxyl group of HMFCA will be oxidized to the aldehyde group through the free radical mechanism to generate the final FFCA [47,48]. Comparatively, for Co@NC catalyst, its catalytic performance can be attributed to the coordination of CoNx to change the electronic state of Co and the synergistic effect of surrounding N atoms, in which Co-N plays a more important role in the catalytic conversion of HMF-FDCA. O2 is partially activated at the C-N sites [13], and then mostly O2 is at the Co sites, due to the rapid activation of electron transfer between Co-N to generate a large amount of O2 -, further oxidizing HMF to FDCA. Then, we propose the following possible reaction paths (Co@NC as an example), the aldehyde side chain of HMF forms a diol intermediate on the catalyst surface through adsorbed OH- in the first phase, and then oxidative dehydrogenation generates HMFCA. In the second phase, O2 is activated into superoxide on the Co-N structure, and then with the assistance of OH-, the β-C-H of the alcohol side group of HMFCA is extracted to generate an aldehyde (Fig. 8B) [49,50]. Obviously, O2 can act as an electron scavenger to remove protons from intermediates during the reaction and the oxidation process of FFCA-FDCA is similar to the first stage, with further oxidation. In particular, the barrier of FFCA-FDCA is 0.81 eV when Co@NC as a catalyst, while the barrier of NC as a catalyst is 1.84 eV (Fig. 8C), the higher potential causes NC to be unable to further oxidize FFCA to FDCA, and Co@NC can, which is also consistent with the results of superoxide radicals formed by the two catalysts, which also ensures that we can selectively oxidize HMF to generate FFCA (Select. 95 %, NC) and FDCA (Select. 98 %, Co@NC). 3.3 Universality of this reaction system The selective activation of the target bond of biomass-derived furfural or furfuryl alcohol is a huge challenge for biomass upgrading and inspired by Co@NC high catalytic activity for the oxidation of HMF to FDCA, we further investigated the catalytic oxidation of various substrates (such as FH, FA, MF) under the same reaction conditions ( Table 2). Obviously, Co@NC shows a good substrate suitability, the four substrates have been effectively catalyzed and oxidized, and the conversion rate has reached more than 97 %, and the –CO/–OH of the substrate can be further converted into –COOH, and the selectivity of the corresponding target product is more than 95 %, which shown that Co@NC catalyst has good universality for the catalytic activity of furfural/furfuryl alcohol activation –CO/–OH targeting to generate carboxyl group, which is conducive to further utilization in biomass conversion. 4 Conclusions In summary, two simple/non-noble metal-based catalysts were successfully derived from the pyrolysis of Zn/Co-ZIF, and the target product of HMF oxidation can be selectively obtained only by changing the ZIFs precursor. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the derived catalysts NC and Co@NC of ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 oxidized HMF to generate FFCA (Select. 95 %) and FDCA (Select. 98 %), respectively. The research analysis shows that pyridine nitrogen and graphite nitrogen in NC and Co@NC have a good preference for the conversion of HMF to FFCA, while the doping of Co-N structure in Co@NC can break the reaction barrier of FFCA-FDCA, further improve the catalyst performance, and generate FDCA with high selectivity. This is because the introduction of Co-N structure more effectively promotes the activation of O2 and generates more O2 -. In addition, the reaction system is versatile and can achieve almost 100% conversion of various furfural substrates to corresponding carboxylic acids. coredata.dc:description: As a bio-based platform compound, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) can be effectively converted into other high value-added derivatives. Here we report two non-noble metal catalysts for the selective oxidation of HMF, NC and Co@NC are easily obtained by pyrolysis of ZIF-8 and ZIF-67, respectively. The NC and Co@NC catalysts oxidized HMF to FFCA (Select. 95 %) and FDCA (Select. 98 %), respectively, using O2 as oxidant. Experimental and theoretical studies show that pyridinic N and graphitic N in NC has high catalytic activity for the oxidation of carbonyl groups in HMF to FFCA, while the synergistic effect of Co-N in Co@NC can completely oxidize HMF to FDCA. DFT calculations show that, compared with NC, the Co@NC containing Co-N exhibits a lower energy barrier during the aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA. And Co-N leads to the conversion of electrons from N to Co and promotes the activation of O2 to form O2 -, and then oxidize HMF to FDCA. Interestingly, our reaction system is universal, and could achieve almost 100 % conversion of various furfural substrates to corresponding carboxylic acid. This study may provide a new/highly efficient catalysts for biomass conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Tunable products of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural oxidation by Zn/Co-ZIF derived catalysts
